verses.text: The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: God initiates the instructions for Israel's sacred times. The Lord’s direct speaking to Moses emphasizes divine authority, reflecting Old Testament patterns for establishing worship.

verses.text: Speak to the people of Israel and tell them: ‘These are the appointed festivals of the Lord, which you shall proclaim as holy gatherings; these are My appointed times.’
verses.comment: God declares specific days set apart for communal worship, giving His people a liturgical calendar. The phrase ‘holy gatherings’ prefigures Christian liturgical worship, showing continuity from Israel’s assembly to the Church’s practice.

verses.text: Six days you shall work, but the seventh day is a Sabbath of complete rest, a holy gathering. You shall do no work; it is a Sabbath to the Lord in all your dwellings.
verses.comment: The Sabbath, rooted in creation, sets a rhythm of sacred time that calls all people to rest and worship. This foreshadows the Christian tradition of keeping the Lord’s Day, emphasizing the life-giving rest found in dependence on God.

verses.text: These are the appointed festivals of the Lord, the holy gatherings, which you shall proclaim at the times appointed for them.
verses.comment: Repeating the appointment of holy days, God emphasizes the sacred structure He ordains for worship, inviting Israel (and by extension the Church) into His divine timetable.

verses.text: In the first month, on the fourteenth day of the month at twilight, is the Lord’s Passover.
verses.comment: Passover marks God’s deliverance of Israel from Egypt, prefiguring Christ’s sacrificial death. This foundational feast connects Old Testament redemption history to its fulfillment in Jesus, the true Passover Lamb (see 1 Cor. 5:7).

verses.text: And on the fifteenth day of the same month is the Feast of Unleavened Bread to the Lord; for seven days you shall eat unleavened bread.
verses.comment: The Feast of Unleavened Bread continues Passover, signifying purity and the removal of sin. The spiritual principle endures in the Christian call to holiness and ongoing sanctification.

verses.text: On the first day you shall hold a holy gathering; you shall not do any regular work.
verses.comment: Sacred assemblies frame the festival and emphasize the communal nature of worship—a practice later reflected in the Christian gathering for worship on holy days.

verses.text: For seven days you shall present food offerings to the Lord. On the seventh day is a holy gathering; you shall not do any regular work.’
verses.comment: The rhythm of offering and rest in this festival points to the importance of continuous worship and dedication, not merely one-time observance, reflected in the Christian calling to ongoing spiritual devotion.

verses.text: And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: God’s direct communication again indicates His control over Israel’s worship structure, guiding the people step by step.

verses.text: Speak to the people of Israel and tell them, ‘When you come into the land that I am giving you and reap its harvest, you shall bring the first sheaf of your harvest to the priest.’
verses.comment: The offering of first fruits anticipates gratitude to God as Provider. The role of the priest as mediator here foreshadows Christ’s priestly mediation in the New Covenant (see Heb. 4:14).

verses.text: And he shall wave the sheaf before the Lord, so that you may be accepted; on the day after the Sabbath the priest shall wave it.
verses.comment: The priest’s act makes the offering acceptable to God, pointing to the importance of ordained mediation. The ‘day after the Sabbath’ has been interpreted by many as a type of Christ’s Resurrection, which occurs after the Sabbath (see Mark 16:9).

verses.text: And on the day you wave the sheaf, you shall offer a one-year-old male lamb without blemish as a burnt offering to the Lord.
verses.comment: The lamb without blemish as an offering foreshadows the sinlessness of Christ, the true Lamb of God, whose self-offering ensures acceptance before the Father.

verses.text: And its grain offering shall be two-tenths of an ephah of fine flour mixed with oil, a food offering to the Lord, a pleasing aroma, and its drink offering shall be of wine, a quarter of a hin.
verses.comment: The combination of grain, oil, and wine integrates the fruits of the earth in worship. Early Christians understood these elements as symbols later fulfilled in bread and wine in the New Covenant sacrificial meal.

verses.text: And you shall eat neither bread nor parched grain nor fresh grain until this same day, until you have brought the offering to your God; it is a lasting statute throughout your generations, wherever you live.
verses.comment: No harvest is to be eaten before the first fruits are offered, teaching the principle of giving God the first and best—an idea retained in traditional Christian order of worship.

verses.text: From the day after the Sabbath, from the day you brought the sheaf of the wave offering, you shall count seven full weeks.
verses.comment: Counting seven weeks introduces the Feast of Weeks (Pentecost), later historically connecting to the outpouring of the Holy Spirit in Acts (see Acts 2:1).

verses.text: You shall count fifty days to the day after the seventh Sabbath; then you shall present a new grain offering to the Lord.
verses.comment: Fifty days after Passover is the Feast of Weeks, or Pentecost, foreshadowing the New Testament Pentecost when the Spirit is given to establish the Church as God's covenant people.

verses.text: You shall bring from your dwellings two loaves of bread as a wave offering; they shall be made of two-tenths of an ephah; they shall be of fine flour, baked with leaven, as first fruits to the Lord.
verses.comment: Unlike unleavened bread, leavened loaves are accepted, indicating the sanctification of all creation. Two loaves may symbolize the unity of Jew and Gentile in the new covenant people.

verses.text: And with the bread you shall offer seven one-year-old male lambs without blemish, one young bull, and two rams. They shall be burnt offerings to the Lord, with their grain offering and drink offerings—a food offering with a pleasing aroma to the Lord.
verses.comment: Multiple animals and offerings point to the abundant gratitude to God, and the requirement for the offerings to be without blemish again foreshadows the holiness required for the final sacrifice.

verses.text: You shall also offer one male goat as a sin offering and two male lambs a year old as a sacrifice of peace offerings.
verses.comment: The combination of sin and peace offerings shows God’s provision for reconciliation and fellowship with Him. The use of both reflects the fullness of atonement and communion.

verses.text: And the priest shall wave them together with the bread of the first fruits as a wave offering before the Lord, along with the two lambs; they shall be holy to the Lord for the priest.
verses.comment: Again, the priest's mediation is necessary, highlighting the divinely-ordained office entrusted with offering sacrifices on behalf of the people—a structure reflected in later Christian worship.

verses.text: And you shall proclaim on that day that it is a holy gathering; you shall not do any regular work. It is a lasting statute in all your dwellings throughout your generations.
verses.comment: The establishment of a permanent holy day for worship emphasizes communal celebration, reflecting a principle that continues in the Christian liturgical calendar.

verses.text: When you reap your land’s harvest, you shall not reap to the very edge of your field, nor gather the gleanings of your harvest. Leave them for the poor and for the foreigner. I am the Lord your God.’
verses.comment: God’s heart for the poor and the foreigner anchors social justice in worship, foreshadowing later Christian teaching on charity and mercy as part of true religion (see James 1:27).

verses.text: And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: God again initiates instructions, confirming the setting apart of sacred days as divinely mandated.

verses.text: Speak to the people of Israel, saying, ‘In the seventh month, on the first day of the month, you shall have a complete rest, a memorial proclaimed with a trumpet blast, a holy gathering.’
verses.comment: The Feast of Trumpets signals the sacred calendar’s progression. Trumpets in Scripture often symbolize divine revelation and coming judgment, elements emphasized in Christian eschatology.

verses.text: You shall not do any regular work, and you shall present a food offering to the Lord.
verses.comment: Rest and sacrifice remain central themes; true worship requires both physical withdrawal from labor and spiritual offering.

verses.text: And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: Repeated phrase marks a new section on the most solemn festival, the Day of Atonement.

verses.text: On the tenth day of this seventh month is the Day of Atonement. It shall be a holy gathering for you, and you shall afflict yourselves and present a food offering to the Lord.
verses.comment: The Day of Atonement was Israel’s most solemn day, focused on repentance. This anticipates the Christian understanding of Christ as the ultimate High Priest and sacrifice for sins (see Heb. 9:24-28).

verses.text: You shall do no work on that same day, for it is the Day of Atonement, to make atonement for you before the Lord your God.
verses.comment: Atonement—covering and cleansing from sin—requires cessation from labor, highlighting the necessity of God’s initiative in salvation, later fulfilled in Christ alone.

verses.text: For whoever is not afflicted on that very day shall be cut off from his people.
verses.comment: Individual participation in communal repentance is essential; exclusion points to the seriousness of sin and its consequences.

verses.text: And whoever does any work on that same day, I will destroy that person from among his people.
verses.comment: Violating this command brings severe judgment—the gravity of atonement is underscored. In the New Testament, disregard for Christ's sacrifice likewise brings spiritual peril (see Heb. 10:29).

verses.text: You shall do no work at all; it is a lasting statute throughout your generations in all your dwellings.
verses.comment: Enduring command underlines the priority of spiritual over material concerns—a principle vital for Christian discipleship.

verses.text: It shall be for you a Sabbath of solemn rest, and you shall afflict yourselves; from the ninth day of the month at evening, from evening to evening, you shall keep your Sabbath.
verses.comment: Observance follows a sunset-to-sunset pattern—a method adopted in sacred traditions for marking holy time, connecting Jewish and Christian practices.

verses.text: And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: With the Day of Atonement complete, the instructions turn to the final festival—Tabernacles.

verses.text: Speak to the people of Israel, saying, ‘On the fifteenth day of this seventh month, and for seven days, is the Feast of Booths to the Lord.’
verses.comment: The Feast of Booths recalls God’s provision in the wilderness, typifying the Christian understanding of living in hope and pilgrimage toward our heavenly home.

verses.text: On the first day there shall be a holy gathering; you shall do no regular work.
verses.comment: Initiating the feast with communal worship highlights the importance of gathering for celebration and remembrance.

verses.text: For seven days you shall present food offerings to the Lord. On the eighth day you shall hold a holy gathering and present a food offering to the Lord. It is a solemn gathering; you shall do no regular work.
verses.comment: An eighth day is added, signifying completion and spiritual fulfillment. Many see the ‘eighth day’ as symbolic of the new creation in Christ, who brings a new Sabbath rest.

verses.text: These are the appointed festivals of the Lord, which you shall proclaim as holy gatherings, to present food offerings to the Lord—burnt offerings and grain offerings, sacrifices and drink offerings—each on its proper day.
verses.comment: God’s order for the offerings reiterates the importance of proper worship; rituals are not random but divinely structured for the people’s spiritual benefit.

verses.text: Besides the Lord’s Sabbaths, and besides your gifts and all your vow offerings and all your freewill offerings, which you give to the Lord.
verses.comment: Festivals do not replace the ordinary gifts and offerings, but supplement daily and voluntary worship. Both scheduled and spontaneous devotion have their place in relationship to God.

verses.text: On the fifteenth day of the seventh month, when you have gathered in the produce of the land, you shall keep the feast of the Lord for seven days. On the first day shall be a solemn rest, and on the eighth day shall be a solemn rest.
verses.comment: Thanksgiving for the harvest is tied directly to worship. A rhythm of celebration and rest echoes the Christian understanding of stewardship and gratitude.

verses.text: And on the first day you shall take branches of splendid trees, palm branches, boughs of leafy trees, and willows of the brook, and you shall rejoice before the Lord your God for seven days.
verses.comment: Celebration with branches echoes messianic hope; in the New Testament, palm branches are used to welcome Christ into Jerusalem, prefiguring His kingship.

verses.text: You shall keep it as a feast to the Lord for seven days in the year. It is a lasting statute throughout your generations; you shall celebrate it in the seventh month.
verses.comment: Enduring celebration ties worship to annual rhythm. Christian faith retains feasts commemorating God’s historical saving acts.

verses.text: You shall dwell in booths for seven days; all native Israelites shall dwell in booths,
verses.comment: Living in booths is a physical reminder of God’s provision and care during Israel’s vulnerable time. Spiritual application calls believers to trust in God’s protection.

verses.text: that your generations may know that I made the people of Israel dwell in booths when I brought them out of the land of Egypt. I am the Lord your God.’
verses.comment: Sacred memory is to be preserved via ritual. This calls to mind the Christian use of ceremony and sign as a way to keep alive corporate remembrance of redemption.

verses.text: So Moses proclaimed to the people of Israel the appointed festivals of the Lord.
verses.comment: Moses' faithful proclamation sets the pattern for leadership in teaching, preserving, and transmitting God’s truth and sacred tradition through all generations.
